sentences.sentence: Nay Pyi Taw (Myanmar), - Opium poppy cultivation in Myanmar declined a further 11% in 2019 to 33,100 hectares (ha), according to the Myanmar Opium Survey released today by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC).
Decreases were observed in all areas except Kachin State, where cultivation increased slightly.
Shan State, which accounts for 85% of cultivation in Myanmar, dropped 14% to 28,000 ha, continuing a downward trend that started in 2015 when Shan had an estimated 50,300 ha of cultivation.
Kachin accounted for 12% or 3,900 ha in 2019, and Chin and Kayah states together for 3% or 1,200 ha.
The national average yield per ha was estimated at 15.4kg/ha in 2019, a 9% increase on 2018.
Jeremy Douglas, UNODC Regional Representative, noted, “the drop in cultivation was again significant last year.
We will continue to work with Myanmar and communities in Shan to assist the transition from opium to sustainable economic alternatives.

We are also discussing options to help Kachin given the situation and needs there.” The report also highlights opium price data, finding that average farm-gate values of fresh and dry opium decreased by 4% and 7% between 2018 and 2019 - over the last four years farm-gate prices dropped a staggering 63% and 51%.
The decline in values combined with the reduction in supply again suggests that demand for heroin in the region is dropping, and that the drug market continues to shift strongly to synthetic drugs.
At the same time, lower farm-gate prices make opium cultivation less attractive and viable, contributing to declining cultivation.
Although demand for heroin continues to drop, organized crime groups still generate substantial revenues from the drug in Myanmar.
Domestic heroin consumption of 6 tons is valued at up to US$290 million, and the export of heroin generates approximately

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

text: Nay Pyi Taw (Myanmar), – Opium poppy cultivation in Myanmar declined a further 11% in 2019 to 33,100 hectares (ha), according to the Myanmar Opium Survey released today by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC). Decreases were observed in all areas except Kachin State, where cultivation increased slightly. Shan State, which accounts for 85% of cultivation in Myanmar, dropped 14% to 28,000 ha, continuing a downward trend that started in 2015 when Shan had an estimated 50,300 ha of cultivation. Kachin accounted for 12% or 3,900 ha in 2019, and Chin and Kayah states together for 3% or 1,200 ha. The national average yield per ha was estimated at 15.4kg/ha in 2019, a 9% increase on 2018. Jeremy Douglas, UNODC Regional Representative, noted, “the drop in cultivation was again significant last year. We will continue to work with Myanmar and communities in Shan to assist the transition from opium to sustainable economic alternatives. We are also discussing options to help Kachin given the situation and needs there.” The report also highlights opium price data, finding that average farm-gate values of fresh and dry opium decreased by 4% and 7% between 2018 and 2019 – over the last four years farm-gate prices dropped a staggering 63% and 51%. The decline in values combined with the reduction in supply again suggests that demand for heroin in the region is dropping, and that the drug market continues to shift strongly to synthetic drugs. At the same time, lower farm-gate prices make opium cultivation less attractive and viable, contributing to declining cultivation. Although demand for heroin continues to drop, organized crime groups still generate substantial revenues from the drug in Myanmar. Domestic heroin consumption of 6 tons is valued at up to US$290 million, and the export of heroin generates approximately
